docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush told members of Congress today that he wanted them to work together in a bipartisan way to produce a bill adding prescription drug benefits to Medicare. People who attended a meeting with Mr. Bush said he made it clear that he wanted a bipartisan compromise, not a bill written by Republicans and pushed through the House and the Senate on party-line votes. Just nine Democrats voted for the bill passed by the House last month.

headline.main: Bush Calls for Bipartisan Bill on Medicare Prescription Benefit

docs.abstract: Pres Bush calls on Congress for speedy, bipartisan effort to iron out differences between House and Senate versions of legislation to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush told members of Congress today that he wanted them to work together in a bipartisan way to produce a bill adding prescription drug benefits to Medicare.    People who attended a meeting with Mr. Bush said he made it clear that he...

docs.lead_paragraph: Almost a century after Californians gained the right to force a recall election against a sitting governor, the state today appeared on the verge of using the power for the first time and authorizing a vote on whether to oust Gov. Gray Davis. California's counties had submitted to the state more than 1.3 million valid ballot petition signatures needed to secure the recall question a spot on a fall special election ballot, state and local officials said. The number of signatures was nearly a fifth of the 6 million state residents who voted in the election last year.

headline.main: A Recall Vote Seems Certain For California

docs.abstract: California appears on verge of authorizing vote on whether to oust Gov Gray Davis, using its power to force recall election against sitting governor for first time; counties have submitted to state more than 1.3 million valid ballot petition signatures needed to secure recall question on spot on fall special election ballot; Secretary of State Kevin Shelley officially certifies results; this is first governor recall effort to make it this far, in 31 other tries; initiative would send state into uncharted political and legal territory; even some basic aspects of likely vote remain in contention; chief among them is whether Lt Gov Cruz Bustamante--a Democrat like Davis--who is charged under state constitution with calling election, would set two-part ballot, one determining Davis's fate and one choosing successor; photo; map (M)
docs.snippet: Almost a century after Californians gained the right to force a recall election against a sitting governor, the state today appeared on the verge of using the power for the first time and authorizing a vote on whether to oust Gov. Gray Davis.   ...

byline.original: By JOHN M. BRODER and DEAN E. MURPHY

docs.lead_paragraph: WARREN ANDERS has a belt buckle larger than many small mammals. Like most cowboys, he's sturdy, serious and polite. He has a honey gelding named Reuben and a dog named Bird. On a breezy summer morning, Mr. Anders stepped into a sparkling white Ford F-150 pickup to survey the Rocking K Ranch, which spills over the Sapphire Mountains of southwestern Montana as far as the eye can see. He drove past the 9,500-square-foot garage and dining hall, then past the pitch-and-putt golf tees, the 3-D archery range, the rifle range and the constructed trout pond and over to the swimming hole called Bikini Beach. Here, he leaned over the dock and turned on a delicate spigot sculptured like an owl's head. This isn't your pappy's back 40, and despite the stalk of timothy grass dangling from his mouth, Mr. Anders, 39, isn't your old-time cowboy. For one thing, he and his family live in a spacious log home. His lunches are cooked by a gourmet chef and he occasionally enjoys a professional massage down by the banks of the blue-ribbon trout stream running through the 7,000-acre property. Unlike most cowboys, he makes a living, and he has benefits that include health insurance. That is because he works for a retired chief executive of a Fortune 500 company, and the ranch that he manages has almost nothing to do with the cattle business.

headline.main: At Home on the New Range, the Cowboy Concierge

docs.abstract: Wealthy businessmen and celebrities who buy ranches to be used as retreats or vacation properties require new kind of 'cowboy' caretaker with skills ranging from managing construction on property to managing wine cellar to tinkering with computers; roping and riding are useful to maintain traditional cowboy illusion; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Twelve people have been charged with being part of a ring that staged phony auto accidents, bribed hospital employees for patient information and filed fraudulent insurance claims and lawsuits, prosecutors said yesterday. Those accused of being members of the group, the ALCAL Management Team, were charged in an 80-count indictment with enterprise corruption, larceny, bribery and insurance fraud. The top count, enterprise corruption, is punishable by up to 25 years in prison.

headline.main: 12 Indicted in Scheme of Faking Accidents

docs.abstract: Twelve members of AlCAL Management group are indicted in Manhattan on charges of staging phony auto accidents, bribing hospital employees and filing false insurance claims and lawsuits that netted crime ring millions of dollars (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of people retiring with health insurance from their employers has dropped significantly since 1996, according to a new study, leaving many recent retirees without coverage for prescription drugs. The study, which was conducted from interviews of Medicare beneficiaries 65 to 69 years old, appears today on the Web site of Health Affairs, an academic journal.

headline.main: Fewer Retirees Are Receiving Drug Benefits From Employers

docs.abstract: Study finds that while overall percentage of Medicare beneficiaries with employer-sponsored health insurance held relatively steady from 1996 to 2000, percentage of younger beneficiaries with coverage fell to 39 percent from 46 percent; drop leaves many recent retirees without prescription drug coverage; study co-author Bruce Stuart says findings show need for Medicare drug benefit and importance of structuring government coverage in way that helps preserve more generous employer-sponsored coverage (M)
docs.snippet: The number of people retiring with health insurance from their employers has dropped significantly since 1996, according to a new study, leaving many recent retirees without coverage for prescription drugs.    The study, which was conducted from...

docs.lead_paragraph: Fewer Retirees Provided With Health Insurance The number of people retiring with health insurance from their employers has dropped significantly since 1996, according to a new study, leaving many recent retirees without coverage for prescription drugs. While the overall percentage of Medicare beneficiaries with employer-sponsored coverage has remained steady, according to the study, the percentage of younger Medicare beneficiaries with coverage fell to 39 percent in 2000 -- the most recent information available -- from 46 percent in 1996. [Page C2.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Mental health care in America is often inadequate and needs ''fundamental transformation,'' a presidential commission reported yesterday. The commission described the present system as a ''patchwork relic'' of disjointed state and federal agencies that frequently stepped in the way of people who were seeking care instead of helping them. The panel said each state should draw up plans to treat the mentally ill.

headline.main: Major Change in Mental Health Care Is Urged

docs.abstract: Report by President's New Freedom Commission on Mental Health says mental health care in nation is often inadequate and needs fundamental transformation to pull together patchwork of disjointed state and federal agencies that often step in way of people needing care; finds that about five to seven percent of Americans have serious mental illness (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bush administration officials acknowledged today that negotiations on a bill adding prescription drugs to Medicare were taking longer than expected, and they urged Congress to keep striving for a compromise between the House and the Senate. ''I am personally concerned about losing momentum,'' said Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, who added, ''This is not a done deal, but it's something that needs to be done.''

headline.main: Administration Voices Concern Over Pace of Medicare Talks

docs.abstract: Sec Tommy Thompson conveys Pres Bush's concern about losing momentum on Medicare drug bill and urges House and Senate to work out compromise (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bristol-Myers Squibb said yesterday that it was starting an internal review of sales and marketing practices to make sure they did not violate antikickback laws or government regulations. The company said in a statement that it could not predict whether it would face criminal fines or civil penalties related to its practices. Under government regulations, drug makers must give their best price to government Medicare and Medicaid health insurance programs. The company said part of the review was to make sure it was complying with those rules.

headline.main: BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB TO REVIEW SALES PRACTICES

docs.abstract: bristol-myers squibb to review sales practices

docs.lead_paragraph: IN an age of clone candidates whose teeth, hair and political platforms are often indistinguishable, even if they purport to be from different parties, James Morrison has fearlessly walked where few will follow. As the Democratic candidate for the State Senate in the 24th District in northwest New Jersey, he has lambasted the complacency of his own party and taken on campaign finance, real estate developers, defense contractors, the war in Iraq, insurance companies, draconian drug laws and the refusal to provide national health insurance.

headline.main: No One Will Ever Call Him a Me-Too Democrat

docs.abstract: Profile of James Morrison, nonconformist lawyer running as Democrat for New Jersey State Senate against Republican incumbent, Sen Robert E Littell, in 24th District in Sussex County; photo (M)
